title.narrative: Hands Off II Sex work Zimbabwe

description.narrative: Hands Off 2 partners work to reduce violence against sex workers at community, national and regional level. Outcomes of partners in Zimbabwe include a strong national sex worker movement, increased access to health and psychosocial services for sex workers, reduction of stigma and discrimination against sex workers and increased respectful behaviour between police and sex workers.

In Zimbabwe, around 63 percent of sex workers in Zimbabwe report having experienced physical, sexual, economic and emotional violence on a regular basis. More than third of sex workers in the experienced violence by police officers. To reduce violence against sex workers, Aidsfonds works together with Pow Wow (sex worker-led organisation from Bulawayo), ZIMSWA (national sex worker-led organisation) and the Sexual Rights Centre (national NGO. The sex worker leadership and mentorship academy will build the capacity of sex workers to advocate for their own rights. Paralegals will continue to support sex workers in accessing legal services and by establishing support groups sex workers will have increased access to psychosocial services.

The most recent data on sex work shows an HIV prevalence of 57.1 percent among female sex workers. It is officially not a crime to sell sex in Zimbabwe. Under the Criminal Codification and Reform Act it is however illegal to solicit clients, live on the earnings of sex work and to facilitate and procure sex work.

The programme’s primary target group is female, male and transgender sex workers, meaning those who receive money or goods in exchange for sexual services, either regularly or occasionally. In Zimbabwe, health care workers, community police officers and high level politicians are also part of the target group.

sector.narrative: Hands Off II Sex work Zimbabwe Human rights
Hands Off II Sex work Zimbabwe STD control including HIV/AIDS
Hands Off II Sex work Zimbabwe Social mitigation of HIV/AIDS

title.narrative: Long term outcome 1.1

description.narrative: A Southern African Sex Worker Alliance is functional and sustainable

title.narrative: SASWA plays a leadership role in regional (and global) forums on key topics relevant for sex workers in the region

description.narrative: To identify if SASWA follows the mandate to actively be representing Southern African national sex worker movements in regional and global forums.

comment.narrative: The work with SASWA is set to begin in 2021

title.narrative: SASWA provides national sex worker movements in Southern Africa with increased capacity, knowledge and skills needed to strengthen the national sex worker movements

description.narrative: To identify if SASWA leads capacity of national sex worker movements by providing technical and organisational support. This indicator includes the implementation of capacity scans/assessments by SASWA among national sex worker movements.

comment.narrative: The work with SASWA is set to begin in 2021

title.narrative: Long term outcome 1.2

description.narrative: A national sex worker movements is functional and sustainable

title.narrative: Amount of direct funding allocated to national sex worker movements

description.narrative: Amount of direct funding allocated to national sex worker movements

comment.narrative: All funds received by ZIMSWA and Pow Wow during the reporting period have been monitored by the SRC, as their host organization.

title.narrative: Amount of indirect funding allocated to national sex worker movements

description.narrative: Amount of indirect funding allocated to national sex worker movements

comment.narrative: The funds received by Pow Wow came from the Red Umbrella Fund through Mama Cash (13251 USD - 11.154). The funds received by ZIMSWA came from ASWA, supported by the Global Fund (5153,83 USD - 4338 euro). In addition 18.041 euro has been alllocated to Pow Wow and Zimswa directly under the HO budget.

title.narrative: Number of districs the national sex worker movement is represented and/ or active in

description.narrative: Number of districs the national sex worker movement is represented and/ or active in

comment.narrative: The sex worker movement is represented in all districts in the country as we are working with ZIMSWA, who has se worker organization members scattered throughout Zimbabwe.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 1.2

description.narrative: A national sex worker movements is functional and sustainable

title.narrative: Sex workers across the country report to be affiliated with a strong functional and sustainable national movement

description.narrative: To identify the common understanding of profession and rights across sex workers as well as monitor how sex workers inspire, inform and motivate each other.

comment.narrative: Sex wrokers across the districts of operation are affiliated to Women Against All forms of Distrcimination (WAAD), ZIMSWA and Pow Wow. These are all sex worker led and representing organizations and collectives.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 4.2

description.narrative: Empowered police officers have improved behaviour towards SWs and KPs

title.narrative: Number of police officers trained in the dignity, diversity and policing training

description.narrative: Number of police officers trained in the dignity, diversity and policing training (female)

comment.narrative: The officers trained here, were invited to a sensitization with sex workers where they were able to hear from sex worker, they experiences with the police and explain to sex workers the procedures that are to be followed when reporting cases at the station. This training will go a long way in improving the way in which sex workers are treated by the police, as they gain a greater undrstanding of the sex worker community.

The officers trained here, were invited to a sensitization with sex workers where they were able to hear from sex worker, they experiences with the police and explain to sex workers the procedures that are to be followed when reporting cases at the station. This training will go a long way in improving the way in which sex workers are treated by the police, as they gain a greater undrstanding of the sex worker community.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 4.3

description.narrative: Empowered police officers have improved behaviour towards SWs and KPs

title.narrative: Relationship building and collaboration results in improved police policy, training programmes and (standard operating) procedures tailored towards sex workersâ€™ and key populationsâ€™ rights

description.narrative: To assess the extent into which interventions under the programme result in structural reforms in police services. This indicator measures the level of commitment of the police to change policy and (standard operating) procedures with regards to the inclusion of the rights of sex workers and other key populations.

comment.narrative: Apolice sensitization was conducted with police officers selected from stations that are sex worker hotspots. These officers were invited in their personal capacity, however we look forward to mobilizing these officers in their official capacity.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 4.2

description.narrative: Empowered police officers have improved behaviour towards SWs and KPs

title.narrative: Self-reported changes in knowledge, attitude and behaviour towards sex workers by the police

description.narrative: To identify if police sensitisation and engagement leads to improved practice and attitude of police officers towards sex workers (female sex workers, male sex workers and transgender sex workers) and other key populations.

comment.narrative: The SRC has developed strong working relations with two police officers, one male officer and one female officer who have gone so far as to come to the SRC space to facilitate relations buildings between the sex worker community and the police force. In addition to this, these officers have cited their commitment to the work of the SRC and building a safer Zimbabwe for all citizens.

title.narrative: Overall programme long term outcome 2

description.narrative: Increased access to, and use of inclusive services for seks workers

title.narrative: Sex workers report to have access to quality sex worker-friendly services

description.narrative: To assess if sex workers are satisfied with the services provided to them and if those services are in line with (inter)national standards based on the needs of sex workers. These needs can be different for female sex workers, male sex workers and transgender sex workers. This indicator covers health services, psychosocial services and legal and justice services for all sex workers.

comment.narrative: A sensitization training was held with services providers from different institutions where sex workers access services on the unique needs of sex workers (in all their diversity). In addition to this, service providers were sensitized on the decriminalization of sex work campaign, that will be led by the HandsOFF2 project.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 3.1

description.narrative: Policies and laws are supportive of the wellbeing of sex workers

title.narrative: Number of national/regional/global level groups and committees in which sex workers are represented

description.narrative: Number of national/regional/global level groups and committees in which sex workers are represented

comment.narrative: ZIMSWA is currently a member of the African Sex Workers Alliance (ASWA) and the Global Network of Sex Worker Projects (NSWP)

title.narrative: Long term outcome 3.1

description.narrative: Policies and laws are supportive of the wellbeing of sex workers

title.narrative: Campaigns or lobby results in a positive shift in practice under (existing) law, guidelines, and (health) policies and practices supportive of sex workersâ€™ rights

description.narrative: To assess the impact of lobby and advocacy programme activities on the environment for sex work. This includes monitoring a shift in practice both with positive and negative outcomes. Improved practice refers to policies and laws supportive of the wellbeing and rights of sex workers, regardless of their gender.

comment.narrative: The decriminalization campaign strategy was developed in 2020, in consultation with sex worker led and serving organizations. The strategy is set to be launched in 2021 however it has the endorsement of the widers ex worker community.

title.narrative: Self-reported changes in knowledge, attitude and behaviour towards sex workers by community leaders

description.narrative: To identify if community leader sensitisation and engagement leads to improved attitude of community leaders (traditional and religious leaders) towards sex workers and other key populations, regardless of their gender.

comment.narrative: The SRC has seen a shift in the attitudes of village Headmen in Esiphezini. During the reprting period, the SRC was able to engage a Headman to resolve conflict between sex workers. He was able to mediate on our behalf which is certainly a shift from the past experience with community leaders.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 4.1

description.narrative: Safe sex work locations with increased respectful interaction between police and sex workers

title.narrative: Number of human rights violations reported to the police

description.narrative: Number of human rights violations reported to the police

comment.narrative: These were cases that were reported to the police either by sex workers on their own, who later approached the SRC for further assistance of cases reported by sex workers with the assistance of the paralegal team.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 4.1

description.narrative: Safe sex work locations with increased respectful interaction between police and sex workers

title.narrative: Sex workers report changes in police behaviour

description.narrative: To identify if sex workers experience less violence and stigma and discrimination by police officers. This includes a measurement of increased confidence to report cases to the police and satisfaction with police service. Because the experience with police can significantly differ depending on gender of the sex worker, this outcome indicator will look at gender disaggregation.

comment.narrative: No significant changes were reported about changes in police behaviour. In fact, police seem to be treating sex workers very harshly during the COVID-19 lockdown, especially if the find them working at night. Sex workers have continued to work in order to sustain their livelihoods despite the lockdown regulations and curfews imposed. Despite breaking the law, it id difficult to advise sex workers not to work because they have families that depend on their income.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 2.1

description.narrative: Sex workers use community led prevention, care and health services

title.narrative: Number of sex workers accessing community-led support after violence

description.narrative: Number of sex workers accessing community-led support after violence (transgender) 25 years and older

comment.narrative: These are sex workers below the age of 24 years, who have been assisted by the rapid response team and peer educators. The assistance here includes referral for medical assistance to a private or public institution (where possible) however during this reporting period, accessing health care services at a public health care facility has been very difficult due to on going strikes by public healthcare workers. No targets were set to reach this group of sex workers however there is need to review this as we have been able to reach them during the reporting period.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 1.3

description.narrative: Sex workers with strong rights-awareness are united

title.narrative: Human rights training results in a united sex worker movement aware of their rights

description.narrative: To assess if there is a strong inclusive sex worker movement able to demand their rights, reaching female sex workers, male sex workers and transgender sex workers. Demanding their rights includes the right to health, peaceful assembly and association and dignity and lives free from violence, discrimination and stigma.

comment.narrative: The metorship training planned for 2020 was delayed due to the COVID-19 lockdown regulations and will take place during the coming reporting period.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 3.2

description.narrative: Stigma and discrimination against sex workers is reduced

title.narrative: Number of community leaders trained on the rights of sex workers

description.narrative: Number of community leaders trained on the rights of sex workers

comment.narrative: During the sex worker household relief programme, the SRC had the opportunity to interact with Ward Councellors and Village Headmen. They were very receptive of the SRC and the work we were doing in their constituencies.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 3.2

description.narrative: Stigma and discrimination against sex workers is reduced

title.narrative: Sex workers report a reduction in experienced stigma and discrimination by their community and by society

description.narrative: To identify a change in communities and societyâ€™s perspective on sex work contributing to a more supportive environment for sex work. This indicator refers to stigma and discrimination in relation to sex workers HIV status and/or gender/sexuality/profession and includes self-stigma.

comment.narrative: Through media monitoring, the SRC has noted an improvement in stories reported on sex wrokers. It is important to note however that sex workershave actually reported an increase in stigma and discrimination in their communities due to the COVID-19 lockdown regulations as sex workers are beign accused of spreading the virus.
